clinical_study.brief_title: Group Cognitive Behavioural Family Intervention (CBFI) for People With Schizophrenia and Their Families
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of Group Cognitive Behavioural Family Intervention (CBFI) for People With Schizophrenia and Their Families: A Mixed-method Study

brief_summary.textblock: Cognitive behavioural family intervention (CBFI) is a brief psychosocial intervention that incorporates the model of cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) into the family context. It builds upon the current trend of family interventions/psychoeducation with refocusing on the cognitive model within the family interpersonal relationship. Existing literature indicates that CBFI may be effective in improving positive and negative symptoms of people diagnosed with schizophrenia immediately following the programme. This mixed-method is to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a CBFI programme for people with schizophrenia and their families in a local context. The findings may accumulate more evidence that CBFI is a brief and effective psychosocial intervention that is adapted to Hong Kong clinical settings.

primary_outcome.measure: Qualitative feedback from the clinicians of the concerned wards

secondary_outcome.description: Psychotic Symptoms Rating Scales (PSYRATS); 11-item hallucination subscale ranging from 0 to 44; 6-item delusion subscale ranging from 0 to 24
Brief Negative Symptom Scale (BNSS); 13-item ranging from 0 to 78
Concise Chinese Level of Expressed Emotion Scale (CCLEES); 12-item ranging from 12 to 48
Chinese version of Experience of Caregiving Inventory (CECI); 66-item ranging from 0 to 264

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived care burden by family caregivers
secondary_outcome.description: Family Burden Interview Schedule (FBIS); 25-item ranging from 0 to 50
Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS); 7-item depression subscale ranging from 0 to 21; 7-item anxiety subscale ranging from 0 to 21

secondary_outcome.measure: Qualitative feedback from the service users and their families

intervention.description: four-week, four-session CBT-based family intervention programme
Treatment as usual in the institution studied

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Service users
- Diagnosis of schizophrenia-spectrum disorders, based on clinical judgement by the treating clinicians
- Aged 18-65
- Able to communicate in Cantonese
Family caregivers
- Aged above 18
- Living with service users
- Able to communicate in Cantonese
- Nominated by the service users
Exclusion Criteria:
Service users
- Having co-morbidity of learning disability
- Organic/neurological conditions
- Substance misuse disorder
Family caregivers
- Having active psychiatric conditions
- Looking after more than one family member suffering from chronic physical or mental illnesses
